feed.title: Laurent Kempé
feed.subtitle: One of the Tech Head Brothers

entry.title: Accessing Dapr secrets building block using Dapr .NET SDK
entry.summary: In all previous posts, we were looking at the Dapr service invocation building block. We have seen how to expose and call HTTP and gRPC services using it. In this post, we will see how Dapr ease developers life when it comes to deal with secrets, thanks to the secrets management building block.

entry.title: Calling Dapr service with gRPC
entry.summary: In previous posts, we focused on Dapr service invocation using the HTTP protocol. Dapr, through its service invocation, can also reliably and securely communicate with other applications using gRPC. We will have a look at this other capability in this post.

entry.title: Service to service invocation with Refit and Dapr .NET SDK
entry.summary: In the last post, we have seen how to call a service from another service using the Dapr .NET SDK. In this one, we will have a look at a possible way to simplify the development of the client code using Refit, the automatic type-safe REST library for .NET Core, Xamarin, and .NET.

entry.title: Service to service invocation with Dapr .NET SDK
entry.summary:
In the previous two posts, we tackled the way to start with Dapr and how to call services. In this one, we will see how we can leverage the Dapr .NET SDK to handle service to service calls.

  • Getting started with Dapr for .NET Developers
  • Using Service Invocation from Dapr .NET SDK

entry.title: Using Service Invocation from Dapr .NET SDK
entry.summary: In the previous post “Getting started with Dapr for .NET Developers“ we have seen how easy it was to expose a web API written in .NET and the power of exposing it through Dapr sidecar. In this post, we are looking at the different possible ways to invoke that service.

entry.title: Getting started with Dapr for .NET Developers
entry.summary: Dapr for .NET Developers is a great book, read in a weekend, to start gaining an understanding of what Dapr is and especially for .NET Developers. In this post, we will see how you can use .NET to create a service and run it with Dapr and what does this provides.

entry.title: Automate developer work using Git Aliases
entry.summary:
I am using Git for many, many years. I am a big fan of it. How could that be different when you had to use versioning systems like CVS, SVN… I even took influence so that the whole company I work for migrates to it.

Over the years, I have used different Git clients, tried to work only from my IDE without much liking it.

entry.title: gRPC and C# 8 Async stream cancellation
entry.summary: In the previous post “gRPC and C# 8 Async stream“, we looked at how gRPC server stream and C# 8 Async stream work great together. In this post, we are looking at the way we can, from the client, stop the server to stream results back.

entry.title: gRPC and C# 8 Async stream
entry.summary:
gRPC and its idea to describe an API in a standardized file, which can generate both client and server code to interact in different languages is a compelling idea.
In this post, I would like to have a quick look at the experience you would have with gRPC streaming capability and the new C# 8 async streams, which sounds like a perfect match.

entry.title: WPF and .NET Generic Host with .NET Core 3.0
entry.summary:
I like very much the idea of a .NET Generic Host in the MSDN documentation:

An object that encapsulates an app’s resources, such as:

  • Dependency injection (DI)
  • Logging
  • Configuration
  • IHostedService implementations

entry.title: WPF and IOC on .NET Core 3.0
entry.summary: At work, we are planning to migrate our WPF application from .NET Framework 4.7 to .NET Core 3.0. The main reason for doing so is that it was always a big pain to organize the updates of the .NET Framework on our customer machines. So being able to bundle .NET Core with our application is a big plus for us. Then, for sure, we are looking for the performance improvements brought by .NET Core and finally the new capabilities brought by the fast pace of innovation of .NET Core.

entry.title: Azure DevOps for Visual Studio Extensions
entry.summary: As you might have guessed reading some of my older posts, I like to automate things which I believe a computer should do in place of humans.

entry.title: Dynamically compile and run code using .NET Core 3.0
entry.summary: Let’ see in this blog post the new possibility offered by .NET Core 3.0 preview 2 to load and unload assemblies at run time using AssemblyLoadContext.

entry.title: .NET Core Community online Hackathon
entry.summary:
On Saturday, June 2, 2018, I had the chance to participate in the .NET Core Community online Hackathon.

As I got up really early this Saturday morning, I took the opportunity to participate. My goal was to see something new and learn a bit about how .NET Core is built and gain some new experience.

entry.title: Automating my development machine installation
entry.summary:
Since Microsoft went to Windows as a service, so since Windows 10, I fully re-install my development machine, a Surface Book, with each main release of Windows.

As I hate to lose time, I searched a way to automate it, so that it is fast, repeatable and does the work, not me.

entry.title: Debugging into ASP.NET Core 2.0 source code
entry.summary: I am just back from 2.5 months unpaid leave which I used to spend time with my family. So, I almost did not spend time with software development. One exception is that I wanted to be able to configure Visual Studio 2017 to be able to debug into ASP.NET Core 2.0 source code.

entry.title: ASP.NET Core MVC app running on Raspberry Pi
entry.summary: After running a first console app on my Raspberry Pi 3, I had to try ASP.NET Core and API. Two weeks ago when I posted “.NET Core console app running on Raspberry Pi”, I could make API working, but I had no chance with MVC. Today it worked!

entry.title: .NET Core console app running on Raspberry Pi
entry.summary:
Now that there is a distribution of .NET Core on a Linux distro running on my Raspberry Pi 3, I had to try it.

In this post, I will explain all the steps I had to execute to be able to run my first Hello World application.

entry.title: Build, ship and run ASP.NET Core on Microsoft Azure using Docker Cloud
entry.summary: In the last posts, we looked at the code to build a HipChat Connect add-on with ASP.NET Core, run the solution in a Docker container and secure the access to the application with a valid HTTPS certificate that we got from Let’s Encrypt for free and finally deploy all of this on Azure!

entry.title: Free HTTPS certificates for Docker containers running ASP.NET Core RC2 on Microsoft Azure
entry.summary: Following my previous posts on ASP.NET Core RC2, Docker and HipChat Connect add-on and Deploying Docker containers running ASP.NET Core RC2 to Microsoft Azure Cloud I needed, as promised in the last post, to come with a solution to secure the whole with an HTTPS certificate!
